text: we abide by the law of the United States
we do not torture in the immediate
aftermath of 9/11 we did some things
that were wrong we tortured some folks
the release of the Senate Intelligence
Committee report detailing grisly CIA
interrogation tactics has reinvigorated
the debate over the US government and
torture this report is too important to
shelve indefinitely I was and remain a
strong proponent of our enhanced
interrogation program they were legal
essential justified successful and the
right thing to do not only is torture
wrong but it doesn't work here are some
of the key moments in the now
decade-long debate
beginning in 2002 the CIA used enhanced
interrogation techniques but they were
kept secret it was a 2003 scandal at the
Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq that first
focused attention on how the United
States was treating its prisoners they
are disturbing and explicit while it was
not part of the CIA program or overtly
authorized the images of prisoner abuse
put the Bush administration on the
defensive they maintained it was an
isolated incident it was the result of
an individual failure discipline a small
number of suspected terrorist leaders
and operatives captured during the war
had been held and questioned outside the
United States in a separate program
operated by the Central Intelligence
Agency by the end of President Bush's
term the existence of the program and a
series of unflattering details had been
revealed in 2005 The Washington Post
reported on the so-called black site
prisons in 2007 the New York Times wrote
about tapes of enhanced interrogations
that had been destroyed it was also
around this time that a new word entered
the wider conversation reporting is an
interrogation technique it induces the
sensation of drowning at the time I felt
that waterboarding was something that we
needed to do and as time has passed
I think I've changed my mind the public
grew more aware and more divided the
2008 presidential primary was a
demonstration of that split some
Republicans said they would continue the
tactics I'm not going to specify the
specific means of what isn't what is not
torture the Democrats meanwhile roundly
condemned the practice what we cannot do
is have the president United States
state as a matter of policy that there
is a loophole or an exception where we
would sanction torture as public opinion
hardened against waterboarding President
Obama ended the CIA program but it was
far from the end of the debate today the
early reaction to the Senate sweeping
indictment of the CIA program appears to
be a continuation of the last decades
divisions Republicans and many CIA
officials maintained that the program
was necessary
these are patriots and whatever the
report says if it diminishes their
contributions to our country it is way
off base while others see the gruesome
new details as a validation of long-held
criticisms the truth sometimes a hard
pill to swallow but sometimes causes us
difficulties at home and abroad but the
American people are entitled to it
history will judge us by our commitment
to a just society governed by law and
the willingness to face an ugly truth
and say never again
